articles.headline: Boeing Pilot Complained of ‘Egregious’ Issue With 737 Max in 2016
articles.snippet: Two years before two deadly crashes, a top pilot told a colleague that a new automated system, known as MCAS, was causing trouble in flight simulators.
articles.abstract: Two years before two deadly crashes, a top pilot told a colleague that a new automated system, known as MCAS, was causing trouble in flight simulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, Boeing has said it had no idea that a new automated system in the 737 Max jet, which played a role in two fatal crashes, was unsafe.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: The Stunning Escape of El Chapo’s Son: It’s Like ‘a Bad Netflix Show’
articles.snippet: Henchmen forced a patrol of armed forces to release Ovidio Guzmán López after he had been captured.
articles.abstract: Henchmen forced a patrol of armed forces to release Ovidio Guzmán López after he had been captured.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Escape, it seems, is a trait shared in the Guzmán family.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: Kurds’ Sense of Betrayal Compounded by Empowerment of Unsavory Rivals
articles.snippet: Abandoned by the U.S., Kurdish forces are doubly angry at who is seeking to replace them: Turkish-allied Syrian fighters the United States had long rejected as extremists, criminals and thugs.
articles.abstract: Abandoned by the U.S., Kurdish forces are doubly angry at who is seeking to replace them: Turkish-allied Syrian fighters the United States had long rejected as extremists, criminals and thugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — The United States had encouraged its Kurdish allies to dismantle their defenses in northern Syria, saying it would make it easier to assure Turkey that the Kurds posed no threat. So in recent months, according to three American officials involved, the Kurds blew up tunnels and destroyed trenches, leaving themselves vulnerable as the United States promised that it would have their back.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: G.M. Workers Begin to Size Up the Deal Their Union Is Selling
articles.snippet: The tentative contract agreement includes a big investment in a Detroit plant that was scheduled to close. But enthusiasm varies among U.A.W. members.
articles.abstract: The tentative contract agreement includes a big investment in a Detroit plant that was scheduled to close. But enthusiasm varies among U.A.W. members.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tentative contract hammered out by the United Automobile Workers and General Motors won’t please all of the union’s members, but it is sure to get strong support at the Detroit-Hamtramck assembly plant.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: As Inquiry Widens, McConnell Is Said to See Impeachment Trial as Inevitable
articles.snippet: With an eye toward protecting the Republican majority, Senator Mitch McConnell is preparing a serious review of impeachment articles he sees as unavoidable.
articles.abstract: With an eye toward protecting the Republican majority, Senator Mitch McConnell is preparing a serious review of impeachment articles he sees as unavoidable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was only a few weeks ago that the top Senate Republican was hinting that his chamber would make short work of impeachment.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Drawn From Poverty: Art Was Supposed to Save Canada’s Inuit. It Hasn’t.
articles.snippet: Indigenous work is all the rage in the Canadian art world. But life in the North is as much a struggle as ever.
articles.abstract: Indigenous work is all the rage in the Canadian art world. But life in the North is as much a struggle as ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAPE DORSET, Nunavut — Hours before flying off to her debut show in Toronto, Ooloosie Saila, a rising star in the Canadian art world, was hiding in her grandmother’s room on the frozen edge of the Arctic Ocean, cowering in fear.
articles.byline: By Catherine Porter and Sergey Ponomarev

articles.headline: Boris Johnson Sends Letter to E.U. Asking for Brexit Delay
articles.snippet: After a rebuke by lawmakers in Parliament, the British prime minister warned that an extension would be bad for both sides.
articles.abstract: After a rebuke by lawmakers in Parliament, the British prime minister warned that an extension would be bad for both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson suffered a stinging defeat on Saturday as Parliament rebuffed his campaign to take Britain out of the European Union by the end of the month and forced him to seek an extension that he had vowed never to pursue.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: In a Strong Economy, Why Are So Many Workers on Strike?
articles.snippet: A decade into the recovery, workers say they’re still dogged by the concessions they made when the economy was weak.
articles.abstract: A decade into the recovery, workers say they’re still dogged by the concessions they made when the economy was weak.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first glance, it may seem like a paradox: Even as the economy rides a 10-year winning streak, tens of thousands of workers across the country, from General Motors employees to teachers in Chicago, are striking to win better wages and benefits.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: After Criticism, Trump to Select New Location for G7
articles.snippet: White House officials would consider another site, the president said, suggesting Camp David was a possibility.
articles.abstract: White House officials would consider another site, the president said, suggesting Camp David was a possibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Saturday that he would no longer hold next year’s Group of 7 meeting at his luxury golf club near Miami, a swift reversal after two days of intense criticism over awarding his family company a major diplomatic event.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Trump Campaign Floods Web With Ads, Raking In Cash as Democrats Struggle
articles.snippet: That campaigns are now being fought largely online is hardly a revelation, yet only one political party seems to have gotten the message.
articles.abstract: That campaigns are now being fought largely online is hardly a revelation, yet only one political party seems to have gotten the message.
articles.lead_paragraph: On any given day, the Trump campaign is plastering ads all over Facebook, YouTube and the millions of sites served by Google, hitting the kind of incendiary themes — immigrant invaders, the corrupt media — that play best on platforms where algorithms favor outrage and political campaigns are free to disregard facts.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Kevin Roose

articles.headline: As U.S. Leaves Allies in Syria, Kurdish Commander Struggles With Fallout
articles.snippet: Mazlum Kobani, whose Kurdish-led force fought the Islamic State in Syria, fears that a complete United States withdrawal could endanger his people and allow the jihadists to regroup.
articles.abstract: Mazlum Kobani, whose Kurdish-led force fought the Islamic State in Syria, fears that a complete United States withdrawal could endanger his people and allow the jihadists to regroup.
articles.lead_paragraph: QAMISHLI, Syria — As United States troops continued their withdrawal from Syria on Sunday, a line of cars carried their routed former allies, terrified civilians and dead bodies out of a pulverized border town that had been besieged by Turkish forces for more than a week.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Fort Worth Police Have More Violence to Answer For, Residents Say
articles.snippet: Black residents of the city complained about mistreatment by the police long before Atatiana Jefferson’s death. “I never was supposed to be arrested,” said one woman. “I was the caller.”
articles.abstract: Black residents of the city complained about mistreatment by the police long before Atatiana Jefferson’s death. “I never was supposed to be arrested,” said one woman. “I was the caller.”
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Before there was Atatiana Jefferson, there was Jackie Craig, a black woman who called the police to report that her white neighbor had grabbed her son — and found herself pinned to the ground by the officer who responded.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Sarah Mervosh and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: Biggest Late-Night Guests Now Bring a News Angle, Not a Movie Clip
articles.snippet: Stormy news cycles, and an audience thirsty for political commentary, have changed what works on TV at 11:35 p.m.
articles.abstract: Stormy news cycles, and an audience thirsty for political commentary, have changed what works on TV at 11:35 p.m.
articles.lead_paragraph: The formula for success on the big late-night network television shows used to be simple. Keep it light, keep it moving and book a major star, preferably one in the news.
articles.byline: By John Koblin

articles.headline: Estate Tax Can Pay Off for States, Even if the Superrich Flee
articles.snippet: New research shows that even if wealthy residents move away, the revenue at death from those who stay outweighs any loss in income taxes.
articles.abstract: New research shows that even if wealthy residents move away, the revenue at death from those who stay outweighs any loss in income taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Arkansas reaped a windfall when a Walmart founder, James L. Walton, known as Bud, died in 1995 with a fortune estimated by Forbes at $1.65 billion in today’s money. The next year, state estate tax receipts jumped 425 percent, to about $183 million in current dollars.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter

articles.headline: ‘There Is No Hope’: Crisis Pushes Haiti to Brink of Collapse
articles.snippet: Haitians say the violence and economic stagnation stemming from a clash between the president and the opposition are worse than anything they have ever experienced.
articles.abstract: Haitians say the violence and economic stagnation stemming from a clash between the president and the opposition are worse than anything they have ever experienced.
articles.lead_paragraph: LÉOGÂNE, Haiti — The small hospital was down to a single day’s supply of oxygen and had to decide who would get it: the adults recovering from strokes and other ailments, or the newborns clinging to life in the neonatal ward.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple and Meridith Kohut

articles.headline: Erdogan’s Ambitions Go Beyond Syria. He Says He Wants Nuclear Weapons.
articles.snippet: A month before invading Kurdish areas in Syria, Turkey’s president said he “cannot accept” the West’s restrictions that keep him from a bomb.
articles.abstract: A month before invading Kurdish areas in Syria, Turkey’s president said he “cannot accept” the West’s restrictions that keep him from a bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, wants more than control over a wide swath of Syria along his country’s border. He says he wants the Bomb.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: G.M. Contract Terms May Be a Tougher Fit for Its Rivals
articles.snippet: General Motors made cost concessions to get the union to accept the shutdown of three plants — a priority that Ford and Fiat Chrysler don’t have.
articles.abstract: General Motors made cost concessions to get the union to accept the shutdown of three plants — a priority that Ford and Fiat Chrysler don’t have.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tentative contract that General Motors has worked out with the United Automobile Workers union is going to raise the automaker’s cost of labor and require a significant cash outlay.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Why Trump Dropped His Idea to Hold the G7 at His Own Hotel
articles.snippet: He knew Democrats would criticize him. When Republicans started doing so, he changed his mind.
articles.abstract: He knew Democrats would criticize him. When Republicans started doing so, he changed his mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: He knew he was inviting criticism by choosing his own luxury golf club in Miami for the site of a gathering of world leaders at the Group of 7 summit in June, President Trump told his aides opposed to the choice, and he was prepared for the inevitable attack from Democrats.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Eric Lipton and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: As Homelessness Surges in California, So Does a Backlash
articles.snippet: Tent encampments across California are testing residents’ tolerance and compassion as street conditions deteriorate.
articles.abstract: Tent encampments across California are testing residents’ tolerance and compassion as street conditions deteriorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Sign up for our daily newsletter about news from California here.]
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Tim Arango and Louis Keene

articles.headline: U.S. Is Quietly Reducing Its Troop Force in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The reduction, which officials say could gradually drop the number of troops by several thousand, is happening even without any deal with the Taliban.
articles.abstract: The reduction, which officials say could gradually drop the number of troops by several thousand, is happening even without any deal with the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United States has been quietly reducing its troop strength in Afghanistan despite the lack of a peace deal with the Taliban, weakening its hand in any future negotiations with the insurgents.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: In Iowa, Amy Klobuchar Gets a Second Look After Debate
articles.snippet: Mired in the polling doldrums, the Minnesota senator drew crowds and new donors after attacking Elizabeth Warren for a “pipe dream.”
articles.abstract: Mired in the polling doldrums, the Minnesota senator drew crowds and new donors after attacking Elizabeth Warren for a “pipe dream.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MASON CITY, Iowa — Before last week, Beth Kundel Vogel was undecided when it came to the Democratic presidential hopefuls.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel
